title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: Glycerol and fructose were confirmed to enhance the production of vitamin B12.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
More
 attention from the aged and vegetarians has been paid to soy-product 
due to its taste, easy digestibility, as well as the association with 
health.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
However, soy-product has a defect of low vitamin content, mainly
 the water-soluble vitamin B12.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: This study was to investigate co-fermentation of glycerol and fructose in soy-yogurt to enhance vitamin B12 production by Lactobacillus reuteri.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: After a serial combination experiments, the co-fermentation was confirmed to enhance the production of vitamin B12 up to 18 μg/100 mL.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
Both supplementations induced the expression of cobT and cbiA
 and functioned to balance the redox reaction.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
Meanwhile, high content 
of fructose supplementation reduced the production of vitamin B12 and suppressed expression of cobT in bacteria.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
It was proved that the vitamin B12
 content of this soy-yogurt is higher than other fermented soybean based
 food and thus can be served as an alternative food for the aged and 
vegetarians.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
Watanabe et al. (2014)
 reported that Japanese natto and Korean soybean products contain 0.1 to
 0.9 μg per 100 g.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
All these samples were analyzed by the 
microbiological assay, which cannot distinguish analogs.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: Hugenschmidt et al. reported that Lactobacillus plantarum SM39 and Propionibacterium freudenreichii used in a cofermentation of whey produced up to 8 μg of cobalamin per mL (Hugenschmidt et al., 2011).
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: Watanabe et al. (2014) reported that the addition of Propionibacteria to cabbage during sauerkraut production resulted in higher concentrations of B12 (7.2 μg/100 mL).
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: Although we produced less vitamin B12 than their fermentations, our samples do not have the pungent odor from propionic acid.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: In this work cofermentation of glycerol and fructose was also confirmed to have a positive effect on the production of vitamin B12 (Table 1).
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: Glycerol is a vital interesting topic not only for vitamin B12 production but also for the growth of cells.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: Glycerol works as an inducer of vitamin B12 synthesis cluster (Roth et al., 1996).
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: In Fig. 1, cobT and cbiA genes were obviously induced by glycerol, but cbiA was induced more than cobT.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: The increase expression of both enzymes accelerated the synthesis of vitamin B12 and led to a higher production of vitamin B12.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: In this condition, vitamin B12 synthesis also increased the production of vitamin B12 analogs.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
Vitamin B12 dependent enzymes in L. reuteri are involved in the conversion from glycerol to 3-HPA in order to regenerate NAD+
 with more ATP generation.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
Some researchers demonstrated that glycerol 
serves only as an external hydrogen acceptor in the glycerol 
fermentation of L. reuteri, and does not work as a carbon source ( Sriramulu et al., 2008).
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: Our work of glycerol used as an external hydrogen acceptor (Table 2) is in agreement with the above results.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text: An obvious shift of end products from ethanol to acetate was observed in our results (Table 2).
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
Similar results were found in the work of Lüthi-Peng et al. (2002)
 and coworkers.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
They stated that a sufficient supplementation of glucose
 compared to glycerol could improve the generation of 1, 3-propanediol 
and acetate, and reduced the accumulation of 3-HPA and lactate.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
Vitamin B12 production (Table 1)
 was indeed improved with the supplementation of glycerol since glucose 
was utilized via a more efficient pathway to generate ATP and glucose 
was not involved in the redox balance, but high concentrations of 
glycerol supplementations in our work definitely inhibited the growth of
 cells.
title: Enhancing vitamin B12 content in soy-yogurt by Lactobacillus reuteri

text:
It may attribute to an activity of glycerol dehydratase 
inhibited by a quorum sensing of reuterin (Bauer et al., 2010).

text:
Eighty-eight strains belonging to 10 species of lactic acid bacteria 
(LAB) isolated from traditional Italian cheeses were studied for their 
reduction activity: Enterococcus faecalis, Enterococcus faecium, Enterococcus durans, Streptococcus thermophilus, Lactococcus lactis ssp. lactis, Lactobacillus paracasei ssp. paracasei, Lactobacillus plantarum, Lactobacillus delbrueckii ssp. bulgaricus, Lactobacillus helveticus and Pediococcus pentosaceus.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: It was observed that the lactococci reached minimum redox potential before the lactobacilli.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: The reduction rate of Enterococcus spp. and L. lactis ssp. lactis was higher than that of the streptococci and Lactobacillus spp.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: All the P. pentosaceus strains had poor reduction activity compared with the other species.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: The E. faecalis strains were characterized by a relevant reduction power.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: In fact, this species showed the lowest Ehmin (−221 ± 13·4 mV), the largest Δmax (326 ± 93·1 mV), and was the fastest to reach Δmax (t*: 1·1 ± 0·3 h) (Table 2).
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: The behaviour of the 10 strains was the same except for VS368, which was the most rapid E. faecalis strain (t*: 0·5 h) and, at the same time, the one showing the highest Ehmin (−189 mV).
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text:
At 37°C, the mean curves for E. faecium, E. durans and L. lactis ssp. lactis
 had similar Eh evolution (sharp decrease around the second hour of 
culture), but the minimum values were different.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: The strains of L. lactis ssp. lactis were more reducing than the strains of the other two species: Ehmin: −162 ± 32·9 mV vs−138 ± 31·3 and −120 ± 29·0, respectively (Fig. 2).
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text:
The 10 strains of E. faecium
 had similar reduction power, although after 24 h of incubation 
three strains, FK5, FK6 and FK7, isolated from Scimudin cheese, showed 
higher reducing activity than the other seven.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text:
The slowest and least 
reducing strain, 174, was isolated from Caciocavallo Ragusano cheese.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text:
The E. durans strains showed similar Eh evolution over 
24 h, except for VS263 isolated from Formagèla Valseriana cheese.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: VS263 was the fastest to achieve Ehmin and Δmax (tmin: 2·0 h; t*: 1·0 h) and had higher reduction power (Ehmin: −171 mV) than the others.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: The L. lactis ssp. lactis strains had the highest reduction activity after the E. faecalis strains.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text:
Their Ehmin values were: −162 ± 32·9 mV, and they were characterized by a rapid decrease in tmin 3·8 ± 0·8 h and t*
 2·2 ± 0·3 h.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text:
Once again ‘atypical’ behaviour was 
detected in the strains isolated from Formagèla Valseriana, namely VS179
 and VS180, these being revealed to have lower reduction power compared 
with the other lactococci belonging to the same species.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text:
Streptococcus thermophilus,
 the major species used as the starter culture in cheese manufacture, 
was the slowest of the tested LAB species.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text:
Its reduction activity 
increased constantly, and it consequently had a smaller Δmax; all the strains reached Ehmin
 at the end of the 24-h incubation period, the exception being O2A 
isolated from Fontina, found to be the most reducing and reaching Ehmin after 14 h.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: Instead, strain LOD11 was the slowest S. thermophilus strain (t*: 4·5 h), however it also had the highest Ehmin (−45 mV).
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: Among the lactobacilli, the highest reducing species was L. paracasei ssp. paracasei: their strains showed the lowest Ehmin (−169 ± 13·8 mV), and were the fastest to achieve Δmax (4·2 ± 1·3 h).
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: The B1B strain showed similar behaviour to the enterococci (Ehmin: −186; t*: 3 h) (Table 3).
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: On the contrary, the BB3 strain isolated from Formai de Mut cheese was very slow: it took 12 h to reach Ehmin.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: The redox curve of L. paracasei ssp. paracasei, comparable with that of E. faecalis and reaching similar final values, shows a more gradual slope (lower Δmax) reached over longer times.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text:
With regard to the strains of L. plantarum,
 the redox potential course is characterized by an initial stabilizing 
period followed by a rapid and consistent decrease corresponding to the 
major Δmax (229 ± 88·6 mV) found among the 
tested lactobacilli.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text:
This species showed good reduction power and was as
 fast in reaching Δmax as L. paracasei ssp. paracasei.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: The lowest reducing lactobacilli were found to be L. delbrueckii ssp. bulgaricus and L. helveticus (Ehmin: −54 ± 20·4 mV and −54 ± 23·8 mV).
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: Furthermore, for both the thermophilic lactobacilli species, Eh decreased slowly (L. delbrueckii ssp. bulgaricus: t*: 6·0 ± 1·7 h and L. helveticus t*: 6·4 ± 1·6 h), the mean curves showing similar evolution over the 24-h period.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text: All the strains of P. pentosaceus had poor reduction activity.
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

text:
In fact, they showed the highest Ehmin (−59 ± 23·5 mV), the smallest Δmax (24 ± 8·9 mV) and were the slowest to achieve Δmax
 (5 ± 2·2 h).
title: Redox potential to discriminate among species of lactic acid bacteria

Most of the selected isolates for this 
investigation came from cheeses produced in the mountains, and it is 
interesting to note that the majority of the strains from Scimudin 
cheese (77·7%) were the fastest to achieve Ehmin, while the 
strains isolated from Formai de Mut took more time to reach the minimum 
Eh value.

text:
Pediococcus damnosus
 LMG 28219 is a lactic acid bacterium dominating the maturation phase of
 Flemish acid beer productions.
title: Comparative genome analysis of Pediococcus damnosus LMG 28219, a strain well-adapted to the beer environment

text:
It proved to be capable of growing in 
beer, thereby resisting this environment, which is unfavorable for 
microbial growth.
title: Comparative genome analysis of Pediococcus damnosus LMG 28219, a strain well-adapted to the beer environment

text:
The molecular mechanisms underlying its metabolic 
capabilities and niche adaptations were unknown up to now.
title: Comparative genome analysis of Pediococcus damnosus LMG 28219, a strain well-adapted to the beer environment

text:
In the 
present study, whole-genome sequencing and comparative genome analysis 
were used to investigate this strain’s mechanisms to reside in the beer 
niche, with special focus on not only stress and hop resistances but

title: Isolation and Identification of the Microbiota of Danish Farmhouse and Industrially Produced Surface-Ripened Cheeses

text:
The present study confirms the presence of the marine bacteria Marinilactibacillus psychrotolerans
 on cheese as this species was found on the surface of cheese D. Both 
French and German cheeses have previously been reported to contain M. psychrotolerans [14, 34].
title: Isolation and Identification of the Microbiota of Danish Farmhouse and Industrially Produced Surface-Ripened Cheeses

text:
It was suggested that M. psychrotolerans
 is transferred to the cheeses from the marine environments via sea 
salt.
title: Isolation and Identification of the Microbiota of Danish Farmhouse and Industrially Produced Surface-Ripened Cheeses

text: The present study confirms that Debaryomyces hansenii and Geotrichum spp. are the dominating yeast species on surface-ripened cheeses.
title: Isolation and Identification of the Microbiota of Danish Farmhouse and Industrially Produced Surface-Ripened Cheeses

text: D. hansenii was found to be the dominating yeast species on the cheeses from dairies C and D, whereas Geotrichum spp. was found to dominate on the cheese from dairy B.
title: Isolation and Identification of the Microbiota of Danish Farmhouse and Industrially Produced Surface-Ripened Cheeses

text: On the cheese from dairy A, Yarrowia lipolytica was the dominating yeast species.
title: Isolation and Identification of the Microbiota of Danish Farmhouse and Industrially Produced Surface-Ripened Cheeses

text:
Y. lipolytica
 is a naturally developing yeast species on cheese surfaces, and has in 
some cases been shown to rapidly outnumber other yeast species including
 D. hansenii and Geotrichum spp. [33].
title: Isolation and Identification of the Microbiota of Danish Farmhouse and Industrially Produced Surface-Ripened Cheeses

text:
Finally, the filamentous fungus Scopulariopsis brevicaulis was found in a high number on cheese A. S. brevicaulis has previously been found in Danish cheese [52],
 and has been subject to spoilage of cheeses due to its high proteolytic
 activity resulting in ammonia production and its production of 
arsenical compounds, e.g., diethylarsine, which has a very 
characteristic garlic-like odour [5].
title: Isolation and Identification of the Microbiota of Danish Farmhouse and Industrially Produced Surface-Ripened Cheeses

independent method DGGE, even though the latter technique proved the 
presence of additional cultures including Str. thermophilus in cheese interiors as well as Vagococcus carniphilus, Psychrobacter spp. and Lb. curvatus
 on cheese surfaces.
title: Isolation and Identification of the Microbiota of Danish Farmhouse and Industrially Produced Surface-Ripened Cheeses

cheese.

entities.form:
capability to produce the novel antimicrobial compound 
3-phenyllactic acid

text:
In this study, 13 lactic acid bacteria (LAB) strains (including 5 Lactobacillus casei, 2 Lactobacillus rhamnosus, 2 Lactobacillus fermentum, 1 Lactobacillus acidophilus, 1 Lactobacillus plantarum, 1 Lactobacillus sakei, and 1 Lactobacillus reuteri species) were assessed for both their antifungal activity against four food spoilage molds (Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, Botrytis cinerea, Penicillium expansum, and Aspergillus flavus)
 and their capability to produce the novel antimicrobial compound 
3-phenyllactic acid (PLA).
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

text:
Results demonstrated that all molds were 
sensitive to varying degrees to the cell-free supernatants (CFS) from 
LAB fermentations (p < 0.05), with growth 
inhibitions ranging from 2.65% to 66.82%.
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

text:
In this regard, 3-phenyllactic acid (PLA) has gained interest in recent
 years due to its effective antimicrobial activity.
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

text: Several studies have reported the ability of many LAB to produce PLA, including species such as Leuconostoc mesenteroides, Lactobacillus plantarum, Lactobacillus rhamnosus, Lactobacillus sanfranciscensis, Lactobacillus acidophilus, Lactobacillus alimentarius, Lactobacillus amylovorus, Lactobacillus casei, Lactobacillus lactis, Lactobacillus paracasei, Lactobacillus reuteri, and Pediococcus acidilactici, although its production has been found to be species- and strain- dependent ( Lavermicocca et al., 2000, Valerio et al., 2004, Li et al., 2007, Gerez et al., 2009, Gerez et al., 2010, Gerez et al., 2013, Valerio et al., 2009, Prema et al., 2010, Ryan et al., 2011 and Mu et al., 2012a).
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

text: Additionally, PLA production has been reported for Geotrichum candidum ( Dieuleveux et al., 1998) and some propionibacteria (Lind et al., 2007).
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

text: De Muynck et al. (2004) studied the antifungal activity of filtered broth from 20 LAB strains by using the agar-diffusion method, reporting that L. acidophilus LMG 9433, L. amylovorus DSM 20532, L. brevis LMG 6906, L. coryniformis subsp.
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

text: coryniformis LMG 9196, and L. plantarum LMG 6907 were the strains with the highest activity against A. flavus MUCL 19945, Endomyces fibuliger MUCL 11443, and Eurotium repens MUCL 15977.
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

text: Schillinger and Villareal (2010) screened 69 LAB to assess their capacity to inhibit the growth of P. nordicum (an ochratoxin producing Penicillium species) in malt extract agar.
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

text:
These authors reported that 37 strains, including L. rhamnosus LGG and L. plantarum 299v, were effective against P. nordicum
 and that both acetic and lactic acids among other LAB metabolism 
products contributed to the observed inhibition.
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

text:
Recently, the 
antifungal activity of L. plantarum IMAU10014 against B. cinerea, Glomerella cingulate, Phytophthora drechsleri, Penicillium citrinum, P. digitatum, and Fusarium oxysporum has been reported ( Wang et al., 2012).
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

text:
An example of PLA identification produced by L. casei 21/1 is provided in  Fig. 4. PLA concentration ranged from 0.021 to 0.275 mM, with L. casei 21/1 and L. rhamnosus
 13075 yielding the highest values (0.275 ± 0.065 and 
0.242 ± 0.054 mM, respectively).
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

text:
In addition, PLA 
production levels were significantly different between strains of the 
same species (p < 0.05), which is in agreement with previous studies ( Valerio et al., 2004 and Broberg et al., 2007).
title: Antifungal activity of lactobacilli and its relationship with 3-phenyllactic acid production

title: Characterization of Carnobacterium maltaromaticum LMA 28 for its positive technological role in soft cheese making

text:
Carnobacterium maltaromaticum
 is a lactic acid bacterium isolated from soft cheese.
title: Characterization of Carnobacterium maltaromaticum LMA 28 for its positive technological role in soft cheese making

text:
The objective of 
this work was to study its potential positive impact when used in cheese
 technology.
title: Characterization of Carnobacterium maltaromaticum LMA 28 for its positive technological role in soft cheese making

text:
Phenotypic and genotypic characterization of six strains of
 C. maltaromaticum showed that they belong to different 
phylogenetic groups.
title: Characterization of Carnobacterium maltaromaticum LMA 28 for its positive technological role in soft cheese making

text:
Although these strains lacked the ability to 
coagulate milk quickly, they were acidotolerant.
title: Characterization of Carnobacterium maltaromaticum LMA 28 for its positive technological role in soft cheese making

text:
They did not affect the
 coagulation capacity of starter lactic acid bacteria, Lactococcus lactis and Streptococcus thermophilus, used in dairy industry.
title: Characterization of Carnobacterium maltaromaticum LMA 28 for its positive technological role in soft cheese making

text:
The impact of C. maltaromaticum LMA 28 on bacterial flora of cheese revealed a significant decrease of Psychrobacter
 sp. concentration, which might be responsible for cheese aging 
phenomena.
title: Characterization of Carnobacterium maltaromaticum LMA 28 for its positive technological role in soft cheese making

text: Cellular concentration of C. maltaromaticum LMA 28 was found to be the main factor involved in the inhibition of Psychrobacter sp. and L. monocytogenes.
title: Characterization of Carnobacterium maltaromaticum LMA 28 for its positive technological role in soft cheese making

text:
The presence of an opportunistic psychrotrophic LAB named Carnobacterium maltaromaticum
 has been demonstrated in numerous French cheeses (Appellation d'Origine

 which could contribute to lipolysis and proteolysis and subsequent

title: Cheese Rind Communities Provide Tractable Systems for In Situ and In Vitro Studies of Microbial Diversity

text:
Collectively, these metagenomic insights 
into the potential function of Pseudoalteromonas suggest that this and other uninoculated yet abundant microbes could play key roles in cheese rind microbial communities.
title: Cheese Rind Communities Provide Tractable Systems for In Situ and In Vitro Studies of Microbial Diversity

text:
Intensive sampling of three batches of cheese over a
 63-day aging period demonstrates that patterns of succession are highly
 reproducible (Figures 7A and 7B).
title: Cheese Rind Communities Provide Tractable Systems for In Situ and In Vitro Studies of Microbial Diversity

text: At the first time point, the community consisted primarily of Proteobacteria, the bacterium Leuconostoc, and the yeast Candida, which can be found at low levels in raw milk ( Quigley et al., 2013).
title: Cheese Rind Communities Provide Tractable Systems for In Situ and In Vitro Studies of Microbial Diversity

text: Whereas Candida persisted in the fungal portion of the community, the Proteobacteria were succeeded by Staphylococcus within the first 7 days.
title: Cheese Rind Communities Provide Tractable Systems for In Situ and In Vitro Studies of Microbial Diversity

text:
As the rinds matured, bacterial taxa Brevibacterium and Brachybacterium and fungal taxa Penicillium and Scopulariopsis
 emerged consistently as a significant fraction of the community (on 
average, >1% in mature cheeses).
title: Cheese Rind Communities Provide Tractable Systems for In Situ and In Vitro Studies of Microbial Diversity

text:
Principal coordinate analysis shows a
 reproducible trajectory of all three communities over time ( Figure 7B),
 with the most rapid changes in composition occurring at early time 
points, which is consistent with previous observations of primary 
succession ( Fierer et al., 2012 and Shade et al., 2013).
title: Cheese Rind Communities Provide Tractable Systems for In Situ and In Vitro Studies of Microbial Diversity

text:
Our
 study provides data, which combined with publicly available genome 
references, represents the most expansive catalog to date of 
cheese-associated bacteria.
title: Construction of a dairy microbial genome catalog opens new perspectives for the metagenomic analysis of dairy fermented products

text:
Using this extended dairy catalog, we 
revealed the presence in traditional cheese of dominant microorganisms 
not deliberately inoculated, mainly Gram-negative genera such as Pseudoalteromonas haloplanktis or Psychrobacter immobilis, that may contribute to the characteristics of cheese produced through traditional methods.
title: Construction of a dairy microbial genome catalog opens new perspectives for the metagenomic analysis of dairy fermented products

text: Several species, such as Corynebacterium casei, Microbacterium gubbeenense, Arthrobacter arilaitensis, Arthrobacter bergerei, Agrococcus casei, Mycetocola reblochoni and Vibrio casei appear to be endemic in the cheese habitat and the environment of cheese manufacturing [14–17].
title: Construction of a dairy microbial genome catalog opens new perspectives for the metagenomic analysis of dairy fermented products

text:
In a first
 example, we compared the genomic sequences of the four Arthrobacter strains isolated from cheese to that of 15 environmental isolates.
title: Construction of a dairy microbial genome catalog opens new perspectives for the metagenomic analysis of dairy fermented products

text: Most bacteria of the genus Arthrobacter are isolated from environments such as soil, where they are considered to be ubiquitous [41].
title: Construction of a dairy microbial genome catalog opens new perspectives for the metagenomic analysis of dairy fermented products

text:
Interestingly, the four cheese strains share several properties that 
may be linked to adaptation to the cheese habitat, such as a cluster of 
five genes involved in the catabolism of D-galactonate, as already 
described in Arthrobacter arilaitensis Re117 [20].
title: Construction of a dairy microbial genome catalog opens new perspectives for the metagenomic analysis of dairy fermented products

As a second example, we compared the genomes of two strains of Streptococcus infantarius
 isolated from Western African fermented milks, sequenced in this work 
(3AG and 11FA), with those of the type strain isolated from infant feces
 (ATCC BAA-102), and of strain CJ18, isolated from Eastern African 
fermented milk.
title: Construction of a dairy microbial genome catalog opens new perspectives for the metagenomic analysis of dairy fermented products

The four strains contain each 1900–2000 genes and share 
1567 genes.

Further study of the gene content of the two Western African Streptococcus infantarius
 strains showed that these strains had acquired the ability to ferment 
lactose through the LacZS system, as previously described for Eastern 
African strain CJ18 [42].

 PG1 was isolated from the dairy plant that produces the smear-ripened

The high proportion of perfect matches 
with reference strain PG1 may thus be explained by the presence of an

1.7% of the good quality matches, respectively.

the Halomonas strains present in the cheese sample are almost

entities.form: increase in the pH of the cheese surface

text:
At the beginning of the 
ripening process lactate, produced by lactic acid bacteria, is 
metabolized by yeasts, primarily Debaryomyces hansenii and Geotrichum candidum, resulting in an increase in the pH of the cheese surface ( Bockelmann et al., 2005, Irlinger and Mounier, 2009 and Montel et al., 2014).
title: Cultivation-independent analysis of microbial communities on Austrian raw milk hard cheese rinds

text:
These processes and the metabolism of yeast growth factors facilitate the growth of coagulase-negative staphylococci such as Staphylococcus equorum and salt-tolerant bacterial communities – mainly coryneforms – such as Corynebacterium spp., Arthrobacter spp., Micrococcus spp., Brevibacterium spp. and Brachybacterium
 spp.
title: Cultivation-independent analysis of microbial communities on Austrian raw milk hard cheese rinds

text:
Finally, bacteria and yeasts cover the entire surface of the 
cheeses.
title: Cultivation-independent analysis of microbial communities on Austrian raw milk hard cheese rinds

text:
Coryneform bacteria are particularly abundant in cheese rinds (
 Delbes et al., 2007, Gori et al., 2013, Maoz et al., 2003 and Rea et al., 2007).
title: Cultivation-independent analysis of microbial communities on Austrian raw milk hard cheese rinds

text: In addition, Gram-negative bacteria such as Halomonas spp., Vibrio spp., and Hafnia alvei have been detected on cheese surfaces ( Brennan et al., 2002, Coton et al., 2012, Feurer et al., 2004a, Gori et al., 2013, Irlinger and Mounier, 2009, Ishikawa et al., 2007, Maoz et al., 2003, Mounier et al., 2005 and Rea et al., 2007).

text: For some time the occurrence of Halomonas in dairy products was a matter for controversial discussion.
title: Cultivation-independent analysis of microbial communities on Austrian raw milk hard cheese rinds

text:
Halomonas was suggested to be an indicator for hygienic deficiencies in cheese producing facilities ( Maoz et al., 2003),
 while it has also been suggested that these bacteria, which originally 
originate in marine environments, are added via sea salt to cheese 
surfaces during washing and dry salting (Ishikawa et al., 2007).
title: Cultivation-independent analysis of microbial communities on Austrian raw milk hard cheese rinds

text:
The dominance of Halomonas
 in short-ripened cheese rinds is most likely due to more frequent 
washing with a higher brine concentration.
title: Cultivation-independent analysis of microbial communities on Austrian raw milk hard cheese rinds

text:
The high abundance of Halomonas
 in VB cheese rinds suggests an important function during cheese 
ripening, particularly of young cheese.
title: Cultivation-independent analysis of microbial communities on Austrian raw milk hard cheese rinds

text:
However, it is still unknown 
whether Halomonas contributes to the flavor or texture of VB or other cheeses.

Coryneform bacteria including Brevibacterium spp., Corynebacterium spp., Arthrobacter spp., Microbacterium spp. and Brachybacterium
 spp. are important for cheese ripening due to their proteolytic 
activity and because they produce volatile sulfur compounds or ammonia (
 Eliskases-Lechner and Ginzinger, 1995).

In

he presence of Staphylococcus equorum

surfaces of long-ripened cheeses has been reported previously ( Gori et al., 2013 and Irlinger et al., 1997).

S. equorum

antibacterial substances, e.g. S. equorum strain WS 2733 produces a peptide antibiotic (macrococcin P1) on the surface of Raclette cheese, which inhibits the growth of L. monocytogenes ( Carnio et al., 2000).

We found the filamentous fungus Scopulariopsis brevicaulis (OTU 1) and the yeasts Pyxidiophora arvernensis (OTU 2), Debaryomyces hansenii (OTU 3) and Nectria mariannaeae

This finding is consistent with recent results on the surfaces
